sen.j: 金胎寺（こんたいじ）は、京都府相楽郡和束町原山にある真言宗醍醐派の寺院。
sen.e: Kontai-ji Temple is a temple of Daigo school of the Shingon sect located at Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto prefecture.
Kontai-ji Temple, located at Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture, is part of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.
Kontai-ji Temple, located at Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture, is part of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 山号は鷲峰山（じゅぶせん、じゅうぶさん）。
sen.e: Its sango (literally, "mountain name", which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Jubuzan, Jubozan, Jubusan or Jubusen.
sen.cmt: 「鷲峰山」の読みは訳出の四つあることがわかりました。
sen.e: Its sango (literally, "mountain name," the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is expressed as Jubuzan, Jubozan, Jubusan or Jubusen.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name," the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is expressed as Jubuzan, Jubozan, Jubusan or Jubusen.

sen.j: 本尊は弥勒菩薩。
sen.e: Its honson (principal image of Buddha) is Miroko Bosatsu (Buddha of the Future, Bodhisattva of the Present.)
Its honson (principal image of Buddha) is Miroko Bosatsu (Buddha of the Future, Bodhisattva of the Present).
Its honson (principal image of Buddha) is Miroko Bosatsu (Buddha of the Future, Bodhisattva of the Present).

sen.j: 開基は役小角（えんのおづぬ、役行者）と伝えるが詳細は不明である。
sen.e: It is said that the founder is En no ozuno, however, details are unknown.
It is said to have been founded by En no ozuno, but the details aren't known.

It is said to have been founded by EN no Ozunu (EN no Gyoja) (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the 7 century), but the details aren't known.
sen.cmt: EN no Ozunu (En no Gyoja) (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the 7 century)に訂正補足しました。

sen.j: 大和（奈良県）の大峯山に対し「北大峯」と称された、山岳信仰の霊地であり、山内には現在も奇岩怪石が連なる行場（ぎょうば）がある。
sen.e: Opposed to Mt. Omine-san in Yamato (Nara prefecture) is, it is also called "Kita Omine (north Omine)", a sacred place of mountain worship and there is gyoba (ascetic practice place) even today where there are a range of strange rocks and bizarre stones.

As opposed to Mt. Omine-san in Yamato (Nara Prefecture), it is also called "Kita Omine (north Omine)," a sacred place of mountain worship, and even today there is a gyoba (ascetic practice place), with its array of strange rocks and bizarre stones.

As opposed to Mt. Omine-san in Yamato (Nara Prefecture), it is also called 'Kita Omine' (north Omine), a sacred place of mountain worship, and even today there is a gyoba (ascetic practice place), with its array of strange rocks and bizarre stones.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 金胎寺は京都府の南東端に近い和束町にあり、標高685mの鷲峰山（じゅぶせん、じゅうぶさん）に位置する。
sen.e: Kontai-ji temple is at Wazuka-cho close to the south east end of Kyoto prefecture and located on the Mt. Jubuzan of which highest peak is 685m.
Kontai-ji Temple is at Wazuka-cho, close to the southeast end of Kyoto Prefecture, and is located on Mt. Jubuzan, of which the highest peak is 685 meters above sea level.
Kontai-ji Temple is at Wazuka-cho, close to the southeast end of Kyoto Prefecture, and is located on Mt. Jubuzan, of which the highest peak is 685 meters above sea level.

sen.j: 南方に位置する笠置寺と同様、山内に奇岩怪石が多く、古くから山岳修行の地として開けていたと推定されるが、こうした山岳寺院の常として草創の経緯ははっきりわかっていない。
sen.e: Just the same as the Kasagi-dera Temple at the south of Kontai-ji temple, there are many strange rocks and bizarre stones and it is presumed that there was developed as a place for mountain ascetic practices from ancient time, however, as is often the case with this sort of mountain temples, circumstances of development is not known clearly.

As is the case with Kasagi-dera Temple at the south of Kontai-ji Temple, there are many strange rocks and bizarre stones, and it is presumed that it developed as a place for mountain ascetic practices from ancient times; however, as is often the case with this sort of mountain temple, the circumstances of its development aren't clearly known.

As is the case with Kasagi-dera Temple at the south of Kontai-ji Temple, there are many strange rocks and bizarre stones, and it is presumed that it developed as a place for mountain ascetic practices from ancient times; however, as is often the case with this sort of mountain temple, the circumstances of its development aren't clearly known.

sen.j: 中世の記録である『興福寺官務牒疏』（嘉吉元年・1441年）によると、金胎寺は天武天皇の白鳳4年（675年）、役小角（役行者）の草創で、養老6年（722年）、泰澄が再興。
sen.e: According to the entry to the historical record of Medieval Age, "Kofuku-ji Temple Kanmuchoso Document" of 1441, Kontai-ji temple was founded by En no ozuno (En no Gyoja (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the 7 century) in 675 and reconstructed by Taicho in 722.

According to an entry in the historical record of the medieval age, "Kofuku-ji Temple Kanmuchoso Document," dated 1441, Kontai-ji Temple was founded by En no ozuno (En no Gyoja (a semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century) in 675, and was reconstructed by Taicho in 722.

According to an entry in the historical record of the medieval age, "Kofuku-ji Temple Kanmuchoso Document," dated 1441, Kontai-ji Temple was founded by EN no Ozunu in 675, and was reconstructed by Taicho in 722.
sen.cmt: EN no Ozunuに訂正しました。前出のため説明括弧削除。

sen.j: さらに大同2年（807年）には興福寺の願安が再興したとするが、創建者を役行者とするのはこの種山岳寺院の草創縁起にしばしば見られるもので、伝承の域を出ない。
sen.e: Further, it is said Ganan of Kofuku-ji temple restored Kontai-ji temple in 807, however, it is quite often said that these sort of mountain temples were founded by En no Gyoja in the writings about the origin and it does not go beyond the patrimony.

Further, it is said Ganan, of Kofuku-ji Temple, restored Kontai-ji temple in 807; however, in the writings about origins it is frequently stated that these sorts of mountain temples were founded by En no Gyoja, but it doesn't go beyond the patrimony.

Further, it is said Ganan, of Kofuku-ji Temple, restored Kontai-ji temple in 807; however, in the writings about origins it is frequently stated that these sorts of mountain temples were founded by EN no Gyoja, but it doesn't go beyond the patrimony.
sen.cmt: EN no Gyojaに訂正しました。

sen.j: 永仁6年（1298年）には伏見天皇が当寺に行幸したとされ、勅願により多宝塔が建てられたという。
sen.e: It is said that in 1298, royal visit by Emperor Fushimi was made to this temple, and Tahoto pagoda (a "multi-treasure" pagoda) was built at Imperial order.
It is said that in 1298 a royal visit by Emperor Fushimi was made to this temple, and that Tahoto pagoda (a "multi-treasure" pagoda) was built in accordance with an imperial order.
It is said that in 1298 a royal visit by Emperor Fushimi was made to this temple, and that Tahoto pagoda (a "multi-treasure" pagoda) was built in accordance with an Imperial order.

sen.j: この多宝塔は現存し、伏鉢（屋根上にある、椀を伏せたような形の部材）の銘から永仁6年の建立と認められている。
sen.e: This tahoto pagoda is existing and it is confirmed that it was built in 1299 with the inscription of Fusebachi (a part looks like an upside down rice bowl equipped at the roof top.)
This tahoto pagoda still exists, and an inscription of Fusebachi (a part that resembles an upside-down rice bowl at the rooftop) confirms that it was built in 1299.
This tahoto pagoda still exists, and an inscription of Fusebachi (a part that resembles an upside-down rice bowl at the rooftop) confirms that it was built in 1298.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。1298に訂正しました。

sen.j: 元弘元年（1331年）には笠置へ落ち延びる途上の後醍醐天皇が当寺に立ち寄ったことが『太平記』に記され、そのため当寺も焼き討ちに遭ったというが、詳細は不明である。
sen.e: In "Taiheiki (The Record of the Great Peace)", it is recorded that Emperor Godaigo dropped in at this temple when he was on the way to escape to Kasagi in 1331, and the temple was set fire and burnt due to that, however, the details are not known.

In "Taiheiki (The Record of the Great Peace)," it's recorded that Emperor Godaigo dropped in at this temple when he was escaping to Kasagi in 1331, and consequently the temple was set ablaze, but the details aren't known.

In "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace), it's recorded that Emperor Godaigo dropped in at this temple when he was escaping to Kasagi in 1331, and consequently the temple was set ablaze, but the details aren't known.
sen.cmt: 説明括弧を"の外に出しました。

sen.j: 寺は康安元年（1361年）に再建された後、永正15年（1518年）に再び焼失。
sen.e: The temple was rebuilt in 1361, and after that in 1518, it was burnt down again.
The temple was rebuilt in 1361, but in 1518 it was burned down again.
The temple was rebuilt in 1361, but in 1518 it was burned down again.

sen.j: 現在の寺観は近世末期に整えられたものである。
sen.e: The overview of the temple today is arranged in the end of the modern times.
Today, the temple's overview places it at the end of the modern period.
Today, the temple's overview places it at the end of the modern period.

sen.j: 標高685ｍの鷲峰山山頂近くが境内になっている。
sen.e: Around the peak of Mt. Jubuzan with altitude 685m becomes precincts.
The temple's precincts surround the peak of Mt. Jubuzan, with an of altitude 685 meters.
The temple's precincts surround the peak of Mt. Jubuzan, with an of altitude 685 meters.

sen.j: 境内は東海自然歩道に組み込まれ、南の和束町側からの道のほかに、北の宇治田原町側からの登山道もある。
sen.e: The temple's precincts are incorporated into part of Tokai Shizen Hodo (Tokai Nature Path), and other than the path from Wazuka-cho of the south, there is a path up a mountain from Uji-tahara-cho of the north.

The temple's precincts are incorporated into part of Tokai Shizen Hodo (Tokai Nature Path), and other than the southern path from Wazuka-cho there is a northern path up the mountain from Uji-tahara-cho.

The temple's precincts are incorporated into part of Tokai Shizen Hodo (Tokai Nature Path), and other than the southern path from Wazuka-cho there is a northern path up the mountain from Tahara-cho, Uji.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除。語順を変えました。Tahara-cho, Uji大文字にしました。

sen.j: 山門から少し登ったところに本堂と多宝塔、そこからさらに登った山頂に石造宝篋印塔が建つ。
sen.e: A little walk up from Sanmon gate (temple gate) are hondo (main hall) and tahoto pagoda, and further a little walk up to the summit stands a stone pagoda, Hokyointo.
A short walk up from Sanmon gate (temple gate) are the hondo (main hall) and tahoto pagoda, and a further walk up to the summit reveals a stone pagoda, Hokyointo.
A short walk up from Sanmon gate (temple gate) are the hondo (main hall) and tahoto pagoda, and a further walk up to the summit reveals a stone pagoda, Hokyointo.

sen.j: 境内東側には行場めぐりのルートがある（1周約3.2km、所要2時間）。
sen.e: At the east part of the precincts is a route for a ascetic practice place tour (3.2km, 2 hours.)
At the eastern part of the precincts is a route for ascetic practice (3.2km, two hours).
At the eastern part of the precincts is a route for ascetic practice (3.2km, two hours).

sen.j: 重要文化財
sen.e: Important Cultural Property
Important Cultural Property
Important Cultural Property

sen.j: 多宝塔 - 永仁6年（1298年）の建立。
sen.e: Tahoto pagoda-constructed in 1298.
Tahoto pagoda, constructed in 1298
Tahoto pagoda, constructed in 1298

sen.j: 延徳2年（1490年）と元和元年（1681年）に修復されている。
sen.e: Repair works were done in 1490 and 1681.
Repair work was done in 1490 and 1681.
Repair work was done in 1490 and 1681.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代にさかのぼる多宝塔として貴重である。
sen.e: It is important that it is the tahoto pagoda run back up to Kamakura period.
It is significant that the tahoto pagoda dates back to the Kamakura period.
It is significant that the tahoto pagoda dates back to the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 石造宝篋印塔 - 正安2年（1300年）の銘がある。
sen.e: Stone pagoda Hokyointo-there is a inscription of 1300.
The Hokyointo stone pagoda bears an inscription that dates it to 1300.
The Hokyointo stone pagoda bears an inscription that dates it to 1300.

sen.j: 木造弥勒菩薩坐像 - 鎌倉時代。
sen.e: Wooden seated statue of Miroku Bosatsu-Kamakura period.
A wooden statue of the seated Miroku Bosatsu, dating from the Kamakura period
A wooden statue of the seated Miroku Bosatsu, dating from the Kamakura period

sen.j: 非公開。
sen.e: Not opened to public.
Not open to the public
Not open to the public

sen.j: 銭弘俶八万四千塔（京都国立博物館に寄託）
sen.e: Senkoshuku-hachiman-yonsento (copies of 8400 metal pagodas made by Sen Koshuku, the king of Wu-yueh in China.)(depositted to Kyoto National Museum.)
Senkoshuku-hachiman-yonsento (copies of 8400 metal pagodas made by Sen Koshuku, the king of Wu-yueh in China) (deposited with the Kyoto National Museum)
Senkoshuku-hachiman-yonsento (copies of 8400 metal pagodas made by Sen Koshuku, the king of Wu-yueh in China) (deposited with the Kyoto National Museum)

sen.j: 史跡（国指定）
sen.e: Historic site (State designated)
Historical site (designated by the State)
Historical site (designated by the State)

sen.j: 金胎寺境内
sen.e: Kontai-ji temple precincts
The precincts of Kontai-ji Temple
The precincts of Kontai-ji Temple

sen.j: 護摩供養 - 9月第一日曜
sen.e: Goma kuyo (fire rituals)-The 1st Sunday in September.
Goma kuyo (fire rituals): The first Sunday in September
Goma kuyo (fire rituals): The first Sunday in September

sen.j: 京都府相楽郡和束町原山
sen.e: Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.
Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture
Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture

sen.j: JR加茂駅 (京都府)より奈良交通バスで原山下車。
sen.e: Get on the Nara Kotsu Bus at JR Kamo Station and get off the bus at the Harayama stop.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Board the Nara Kotsu Bus at JR Kamo Station, and exit the bus at the Harayama stop.
Board the Nara Kotsu Bus at JR Kamo Station, and exit the bus at the Harayama stop.

sen.j: 徒歩約1時間。
sen.e: About 1 hour walk from there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: It's a walk of approximately an hour from that point.
It's a walk of approximately an hour from that point.

sen.j: 寺は京都市伏見区醍醐の金剛王院一言寺（いちごんじ）が管理している。
sen.e: The temple is managed by Kongo Oin Ichigon-ji Temple at Daigo, Fushimi-ku Ward, Kyoto City.
The temple is managed by Kongo Oin Ichigon-ji Temple, which is located at Daigo, Fushimi-ku Ward, Kyoto City.
The temple is managed by Kongoo-in Ichigon-ji Temple, which is located at Daigo, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: Kongoo-in に訂正しました。-ku削除しました。
